qas.question: What does the film's quantum efficiency limit?
What speed of film is produced by insensitive film?
What leads to lower quality images?
What types of film are considered fast films?
What effect does highly sensitive film have on images?
What does insensitive film with a faster speed index need?
What does a sensitive film more of?

plausible_answers.text: reduction of exposure corresponding to use of higher sensitivities generally leads to reduced image quality

qas.question: How is digital photography different from film?
Higher sensitivity leads to greater what?
What does a grainier image limit?

context: Relatively insensitive film, with a correspondingly lower speed index, requires <b5_0>more exposure to <b6_0>light<b6_0/><b5_0/> to produce the same image density as a more sensitive film, and is thus commonly termed a <a1_0>slow film<a1_0/>. <a3_0>Highly sensitive films<a3_0/> are correspondingly termed fast films. In both digital and film photography, the <a2_0><b7_0>reduction of exposure<a2_0/> corresponding to use of higher sensitivities generally leads to <a4_0>reduced <b8_0>image quality<b8_0/><b7_0/><a4_0/> (via coarser film grain or higher image noise of other types). In short, the higher the sensitivity, the grainier the image will be. Ultimately <a0_0>sensitivity<a0_0/> is limited by <b9_0>the quantum efficiency<b9_0/> of the film or sensor.
